title: Associations
narrative:
Sprouts is a property library with a heavy focus on bridging the
    gap between classical place oriented programming and modern
    data oriented programming.
    This is why sprouts has both the `Tuple` and `Association` classes.
    The `Association` class is a value object that represents a set of
    key-value pairs. You can think of it as an immutable map, but with
    an API that is designed around transforming the data in the map
    rather than mutating it.

features.id: An empty association is created by supplying the type of the key and value
An association is invariant to a map. [0]

blocks.text: We apply the operations to the associations and the map for the first time.
The associations and the map are equal in terms of size, keys, and values.
We apply the operations to the associations and the map a few more times.
The associations and the map are still equal in terms of size, keys, and values.
We can lookup any value from its corresponding key.
code: map.values() as Set == map.keySet().collect { key -> associations.get(key).orElseThrow(MissingItemException::new) } as Set

blocks.text: We use the `toMap()` method to convert the association to a map.
The converted map is equal to the reference map.

new Tuple2(Operation.ADD, 'a'),
            new Tuple2(Operation.ADD, 'b'),
            new Tuple2(Operation.ADD, 'c')
        ]

features.id: Association maintains full invariance with Map across all operations.

blocks.text: Fresh association and reference map
Apply operations 3 times
Immediate invariance
We verify the `Iterable` implementation of the association by iterating over it.
The pair set is equal to the map and all sizes match.
code: pairSet == map.collect({ k, v -> Pair.of(k, v) }).toSet()

features.id: Two associations the the same operations applied to them are always equal. [0]

blocks.text: We create an association and a map as well as a closure to apply the operations to them.
We apply the operations to two associations and the map for the first time.
We apply some more custom operations on top:
The two associations are equal.
Their hash codes are equal.
We update the second association to be a bit different.
The two associations are not equal.
Their hash codes are not equal.

operations:
new Tuple2(Operation.ADD, 'a'),
            new Tuple2(Operation.ADD, 'b'),
            new Tuple2(Operation.ADD, 'c')
        ]

new Tuple2(Operation.REMOVE, 'a'),
            new Tuple2(Operation.REMOVE, 'b'),
            new Tuple2(Operation.REMOVE, 'c')
        ]

features.id: The `replace` method replaces the value of a key with a new value, if and only if the key is present.

blocks.text: We add some values to the association.
We replace the value of a key that is present.
The value of the key is replaced.
The size of the association remains the same.
We call the `replace` method with a key that is not present.
The size of the association remains the same.
The value of the key is not replaced.

The association contains the values.

features.id: Use `putAll(Collection<Pair>)` to populate an association at once from multiple pairs.

extraInfo:
This method ensures compatibility with the `Collection` interface, which
            is especially useful when you have a list of pairs that you want to
            populate the association with.

blocks.text: We add some values to the association.
The association contains the values.

features.id: Use `putAll(Set<Pair>)` to populate an association at once from multiple pairs.

extraInfo:
This method ensures compatibility with the `Set` interface, which
            is especially useful when you have a set of pairs that you want to
            populate the association with.

features.id: The `putIfAbsent(K, V)` method adds a key-value pair to the association if, and only if, the key is not present.

blocks.text: We create an association between shorts and chars and add a bunch of entries to the association.
We add a new entry to the association.
code: associations = associations.putIfAbsent(77 as short, 'w' as char)

blocks.text: The new entry is added to the association.
We try to add an entry with a key that is already present.
code: associations = associations.putIfAbsent(44 as short, 'v' as char)

blocks.text: The association remains the same.
We now ry this for every key in the association.

features.id: The classTyped method returns the correct class and handles null parameters
The of factory method throws NPE for null parameters
The `entrySet` is immutable and contains correct pairs
You can iterate over the `entrySet` of all pairs in an `Association`.
replaceAll with Map only updates existing keys

code: var replacementMap = [a:10, d:40, c:30] as Map

features.id: The `retainAll` method keeps only specified keys
The `putIfAbsent` does not overwrite an existing value already stored in an association.
Associations with same entries in different order are equal
values() contains all values including duplicates
replaceAll ignores non-existing keys in replacement stream
clear on empty association returns an empty instance
The `Association` class is an `Iterable` which allows you to iterate over its entries.
Use `Association.collectorOf(Class,Class)` to collect a stream of `Pair`s into a new `Association`.
